headline: Why You Should Consider a Career in Artificial Intelligence?
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'givenName': 'Lahari', 'name': 'Lahari', 'url': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net/author/lahari'}]
name: Why You Should Consider a Career in Artificial Intelligence?
itemListElement: [{'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 1, 'name': 'Home', 'item': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net'}, {'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 2, 'name': 'Artificial Intelligence', 'item': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net/artificial-intelligence'}, {'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 3, 'name': 'Why You Should Consider a Career in Artificial Intelligence?', 'item': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net/artificial-intelligence/why-you-should-consider-a-career-in-artificial-intelligence'}]
articleBody: Artificial Intelligence has the potential to change the face of the world in ten years at a pace which will dwarf even the changes caused by the Internet and the Industrial Revolution together. Hence, for one's job to remain safe in the future, it becomes essential to dive deep into the exciting world of AI.This would range from artificial intelligence curriculum developers and regional language AI trainers to policy and regulatory experts and AI teachers. There are many benefits associated with why you should consider a career in artificial intelligence..Why a Career in Artificial Intelligence is the Correct Choice?.There are several reasons that make artificial intelligence a potential career option. Here are some major reasons why a job in AI would be quite enriching:.1. Fast-Growing Industry: AI is one of the most exciting and fastest-growing fields in the world today. If anything occupies top rankings in technological development, then it is AI. Various industries ranging from manufacturing and transportation to health and entertainment could make use of this technology. This constant spike in demand creates many job opportunities for AI professionals.2. High Demand and Competitive Salary: There are few competent AI practitioners for the available talent pool for the job. For those desiring to engage in it, a shortage in AI competence would mean a competitive salary and an attractive compensation package. Most AI experts enjoy above-average pay and superb opportunities for professional growth.3. Diverse Application: Artificial Intelligence is one of the most diversified professional paths on a platter full of applications. You could be doing everything from setting up recommendation engines and intelligent systems to computer vision, Natural Language Processing, business process optimization, and autonomous vehicles. The options are plenty, and your passions can be pursued to be an expert in many of the subfields. .4. Intellectual Stimulation: Artificial intelligence requires solving tricky issues and enhancing the capabilities of robots. It, therefore, is a field that is intellectually stimulating and requires lifelong study. Working on the idea of giving intelligent systems the power to think and coming up with state-of-the-art algorithms is intellectually challenging.5. Impactful and Meaningful Work: Artificial intelligence can transform sectors of the economy, increase productivity, and make positive social change. You can further expand in the frontier of Artificial Intelligence to help solve some of the problems .Like enhance the customer experience, change the face of healthcare delivery, or even make scientific discoveries. Probably one of the most alluring factors about this field is that a career in Artificial Intelligence gives one the chance to really make an impact on people.6. Constant Learning and Innovations: Artificial intelligence as a subject of study is itself emerging in nature. By the very nature, you will be introducing a new technology with AI; you will always remain at the forefront of state-of-the-art approaches and be current with science. The nature of the field is such that it assures continuous learning accompanied by personal growth.7. Interdisciplinary Nature: Artificial Intelligence is itself a subject, and hence it has interdisciplinary nature. The concepts are hence, borrowed from the disciplines of computer science, neuroscience, statistics, mathematics, and cognitive psychology. Hence, it offers scope for creativity and exchange of ideas by providing an opportunity for working on multidisciplinary projects and collaboration with experts belonging to diversified subjects.8. Entrepreneurial Opportunities: AI-driven enterprises are on an increasing trend; it happens to be one field that is extremely friendly towards entrepreneurship in its ways. Artificial intelligence knowledge will help in the designing, development, and launch of intelligent products and services if you have any creative idea. Having AI expertise along with an entrepreneurial mindset will help you in starting and scaling your own profitable businesses. .9. Global Significance and Effect: Artificial intelligence has a global factor; research and applications have been going on throughout the world. Working on foreign projects, collaboration with people from other countries and cultures are some opportunities that are brought forth by a career in artificial intelligence.10. Constant Career Improvement: AI is at an initial stage; therefore, the career path has huge scope for professional development and growth. With enhanced skills and expertise in AI, one can take his/her resume ahead toward specialization of jobs, team management, or research and academic leadership in academia or industry that helps to set the pace for AI..How Can We Begin a Career in AI and Machine Learning?.Consider a career in artificial intelligence or machine learning as it is a very interesting but at the same time rewarding experience. You can begin your career in this field by doing the following:.Master the Fundamentals: Provide a strong foothold toward basic ideas and concepts of AI and Machine Learning. Learning in areas like statistical models, algorithms, feature engineering, data pretreatment, and evaluation methods, all form part of this.Learn to Program: Most AI and machine learning tasks will require a very good understanding and expertise in programming. So, learn one of the frequently used languages in the domain, like Python, and familiarize yourself with the tools and frameworks—TensorFlow, PyTorch, scikit-learn, etc. Have practice writing code for the implementation and experimentation of various algorithms on machine learning.Learn Statistics and Mathematics: Machine learning and Artificial Intelligence are mostly based on mathematical concepts. Familiarise yourself with statistics, probability theory, calculus, and linear algebra; this will let you realize which concepts and techniques are at the core of machine learning..Learn from Online Resources: You should learn artificial intelligence and machine learning from all online resources you can find. From Coursera, edX, and Udemy, you have full courses and tutorials regarding these topics. There are a number of websites, forums, and YouTube channels focused on teaching about AI and machine learning.Work on Projects That Involve Real Problems: In AI and machine learning, doing something involves real-world experiences. Take up practical projects and use what you've learned. Start off with the simple tasks, such as picture classification or some simple outcome prediction problems, and then graduate onto more complex tasks. Websites like Kaggle give a chance for exposure to tournaments or datasets to help in acquiring skills.Participate in Various Online Communities: This should include online forums, communities, and social media networks to be able to contribute to the community concerned with artificial intelligence and machine learning. Post in discussions or questions and learn from experts and peers. This will help you be up-to-date regarding the latest trends and happenings about this industry..Follow Formal Education: You may also want to consider attending a formal school on the fields of AI or machine learning. Many universities are already offering degree programs or certifications specializing in these areas. Formal education will provide you with networking, structured curriculum, and research opportunities.Stay updated and learn continuously: AI and machine learning are areas of fast-evolving research. Stay updated with the newest published research; attending workshops and conferences is also critical, along with keeping up with the latest in trade journals and blogs. One needs to keep learning to be competitive and informed about innovations.Keep a portfolio of your work: As you go through the class assignments and start building up experience, put together a portfolio with your work. It could contain code repositories, project descriptions, or demos for machine learning models. Having a good portfolio really helps when you finally start applying for positions or freelance opportunities.Look at jobs and internships: Apply to AI/machine learning internships or entry-level positions. Apply in practice by working with the best in the industry. Utilize professional networks, AI-specific job boards, or online employment portals to find positions aligned with your interests. .Conclusion:.In summary, the career path of artificial intelligence offers several compelling reasons to pursue it. From its rapid growth and high demand to its diverse applications across industries, AI offers intellectual stimulation, impactful work, and continuous learning.In addition to this, its interdisciplinary nature enables creativity and collaboration, while millions of entrepreneurial ventures GDP in AI-driven innovation abound. Global in its significance, exciting as career paths, AI has much to offer a budding professional looking to explore the field about to revolutionize the future of AI..FAQs.1.What is the educational requirement for a job in AI?While a strong background in computer science, mathematics, and statistics is very useful, AI embraces a further-reaching background that could be in engineering, physics, neuroscience, or even social sciences. Most positions working in AI require at least a bachelor's degree in some related field; higher-level jobs typically call for at least a master's or PhD.2 .What are the key skills needed to succeed in AI?The most critical skills that are required in this regard are Programming languages, especially Python, knowledge of algorithms and data structures, proficiency in machine learning frameworks like TensorFlow or PyTorch, domains of statistics and probability, and robust problem-solving abilities. Soft skills that include communication, creativity, team working are valued as well.3.  What are the Job Prospects and Salary Expectations in AI?This demand has increased enormously in various sectors—from healthcare and financial organizations to the automotive and technology sectors. Salaries vary widely by experience, location, and role; however, on average, AI veterans get above-average salaries with highly competitive pay packages and roaming opportunities. 4. What are the ethical concerns of AI Careers?The ethical concerns with the role of AI revolve around bias in algorithms, data privacy, transparency, accountability, and the socio-economic impact potential of AI-driven automation. Professionals working in AI need to understand this and work towards responsible AI solutions for societal good, mitigating harmful effects. 5. How can we start a career in Artificial Intelligence  when it is completely new?Start with the basics by following some online courses, tutorials and reading books related to AI, machine learning, etc. Hansel and Gretel cannot but leave tracks as they go on to code, practicing the implementation of AI algorithms through practical projects and competitions too. One will need to network with professionals in the field and seek interns or entry-level positions for hands-on, valuable work experience and mentorship. Keeping the knowledge up-to-date and studying innovations regarding AI is also necessary for further career development.

Title: The Future of Work in the Age of Artificial Intelligence - elblog.pl
description: The Future of Work in the Age of Artificial Intelligence - elblog.pl
og:description: The Future of Work in the Age of Artificial Intelligence - elblog.pl
article text:
Posted on June 18, 2024 by Lidia PerskaThe Future of Work in the Age of Artificial Intelligence  Fears of Automation: The rise of artificial intelligence has sparked concerns about the future of work, with many worrying about potential job losses due to AI advancements. However, a recent study indicates that AI is experiencing a slowdown in evolution after a rapid surge, attributing the initial growth spurt to the abundance of data available on search engines. With the rate of data growth slowing down, the study suggests that AI may struggle to offer anything truly innovative beyond processing existing information.Human Creativity vs. AI: While AI may excel at analyzing big data, human creativity remains unmatched. AI systems are limited to providing answers based on available information, lacking the ability to offer novel solutions or creative insights. Humans, on the other hand, continue to innovate, devise groundbreaking ideas, and tackle problems with ingenuity that AI cannot replicate.The Trust Factor: Another crucial aspect is the level of trust that can be placed in AI to replace human decision-makers. The inherent trust and accountability that humans seek in critical decision-making processes are qualities that AI currently lacks. The need for reasoned discussions, warnings, and consequences delivered by a human touch underscores the irreplaceable role of humans in decision-making.Looking Ahead: As the debate on AI and automation continues, the essence of human ingenuity and adaptability remains paramount. While the allure of AI advancements is undeniable, the unique capabilities of human intellect and creativity ensure that humans will continue to play a pivotal role in shaping the future workforce. The symbiotic relationship between humans and AI is poised to define the future landscape of work, with innovation and human touch remaining indispensable elements in the ever-evolving technological era.Additional Facts:
– One important consideration in the future of work is the rise of the gig economy, where temporary and flexible jobs are more prevalent. This shift can be attributed to technology platforms that connect freelance workers with tasks and projects, providing both opportunities and challenges for workers in terms of job security and benefits.
– Upskilling and reskilling programs are becoming increasingly crucial as technology rapidly evolves. Continuous learning and acquiring new skills are essential for individuals to remain competitive in the workforce, especially in areas where AI and automation are replacing traditional job roles.Key Questions:
1. How can policymakers and businesses ensure a smooth transition for workers affected by automation and AI?
2. What ethical considerations should be addressed when integrating AI into the workforce?
3. How can organizations balance the need for efficiency with the preservation of human creativity and decision-making?Advantages and Disadvantages:
– Advantages: AI and automation can increase productivity, efficiency, and accuracy in various tasks, leading to cost savings and improved outcomes. They can also handle repetitive or dangerous tasks, allowing humans to focus on more complex and creative work.
– Disadvantages: Concerns about job displacement, loss of human touch in interactions, and potential biases in AI algorithms pose challenges. Moreover, the rapid pace of technological advancement may outstrip the ability of some workers to adapt, leading to increased inequality in the workforce.Related Links:
– World Economic Forum
– Brookings Institution  Categories$$$, Big Data

article text:
HomeTechAI aptitude is now more important than work experience. Here’s how job-seekers...
Tech

AI aptitude is now more important than work experience. Here’s how job-seekers can adapt

Hiring for non-technical roles went up 323% in the last 8 years. Businesses are turning to non-technical talent with the skills to apply generative AI tools like ChatGPT and Copilot.

 Andrea Willige

16 June, 2024 10:04 pm IST 










FacebookTwitterWhatsAppLinkedin




Representational image | Photo: pexels.com
Follow Us :












	Text Size:
A-
A+



AI skills could soon rival experience when employers select job candidates.
Research from Microsoft, LinkedIn and PwC underlines how quickly AI is changing profiles and suggests how job seekers need to adapt to succeed.
The World Economic Forum’s Good Work Alliance and Education 4.0 framework focus on deploying AI effectively and responsibly and ensuring that education systems provide the next generation of workers with AI skills training.


AI aptitude could soon rival experience when choosing between job candidates. This is according to a new international study by Microsoft and LinkedIn on labour and recruitment trends due to the rise of generative AI. The research also predicts the rise of AI super users as the labour market – which has already undergone significant change in recent years – will shift again.

The 2024 Work Trend Index Annual Report draws on a survey of 31,000 people across 31 countries, hiring trends from LinkedIn, Microsoft 365 productivity data and research with Fortune 500 companies.


Generative AI could give job candidates an edge


The research reveals that three-quarters of people surveyed use generative AI at work, with the majority (78%) bringing their own AI tools into the workplace, especially in small and medium-sized businesses.Play VideoPlaySkip BackwardSkip ForwardUnmuteCurrent Time 0:00/Duration 25:43Loaded: 2.31%00:00Stream Type LIVESeek to live, currently behind liveLIVERemaining Time -25:43 1xPlayback RateChaptersChaptersDescriptionsdescriptions off, selectedCaptionscaptions settings, opens captions settings dialogcaptions off, selectedAudio Trackdefault, selectedPicture-in-PictureFullscreenThis is a modal window.Beginning of dialog window. Escape will cancel and close the window.TextColorWhiteBlackRedGreenBlueYellowMagentaCyanOpacityOpaqueSemi-TransparentText BackgroundColorBlackWhiteRedGreenBlueYellowMagentaCyanOpacityOpaqueSemi-TransparentTransparentCaption Area BackgroundColorBlackWhiteRedGreenBlueYellowMagentaCyanOpacityTransparentSemi-TransparentOpaqueFont Size50%75%100%125%150%175%200%300%400%Text Edge StyleNoneRaisedDepressedUniformDrop shadowFont FamilyProportional Sans-SerifMonospace Sans-SerifProportional SerifMonospace SerifCasualScriptSmall CapsReset restore all settings to the default valuesDoneClose Modal DialogEnd of dialog window.Advertisement


					Show Full Article
					



AI emerges as a tool to help people deal with an increased pace and volume of work that more than two-thirds of respondents struggle with (68%), helping them offload menial tasks.


However, many of those drawing on AI at work fear that doing so might make them look replaceable (53%) and worry that AI could replace their jobs (45%).

But it looks like the opposite could be the case.
Over the past eight years, hiring for technical AI roles was up 323%, and businesses are now turning to non-technical talent with the skills to apply generative AI tools like ChatGPT and Copilot.

Two-thirds of business leaders surveyed say they wouldn’t hire a candidate without AI skills. Nearly three-quarters said they would rather hire a less experienced candidate with AI skills than a more experienced candidate without them.

AI specialist skills command a premium


This trend is consistent with PwC’s 2024 AI Jobs Barometer, which found that jobs requiring AI specialist skills are growing 3.5 times faster than all jobs combined. The exponential need for AI-qualified staff has been on an upward trajectory since 2016 – well before the advent of ChatGPT and other generative AI models.

Moreover, PwC’s analysis of half a billion job ads from 15 countries shows that, on average, AI specialist jobs command up to a 25% premium in pay. While technologists see some of the highest wage premiums, AI skills also pay dividends for professionals such as lawyers, sales and marketing managers, and accountants.

This further underlines that AI skills are needed across roles and industries. The top three occupations that have added AI to their skills and aptitudes on LinkedIn are creatives: content writers, graphic designers and marketing managers. Following hot on their heels are entrepreneurs and business professionals, along with the web and software developers you might more naturally expect to find on the list.
The rise of the AI super user


Workers clearly understand the role of AI for advancing their career prospects.


More than three-quarters of people surveyed for Microsoft and LinkedIn’s 2024 Work Trend Index felt that AI skills will be necessary for staying competitive in the job market. They also view AI knowledge as a way to get promoted faster (69%) and broaden their job opportunities (79%).

And people are acting on it: attendance of LinkedIn Learning courses on AI for non-technical professionals has increased 160% in the past six months.
The research predicts that AI upskilling – whether through formal learning or simply by using AI tools in the workplace – may lead to the rise of ‘AI power users’.

Power users are those who are ahead of the curve in terms of their AI use. They use it several times a week at work, benefitting from making their workload more manageable, boosting their creativity or helping them focus on the most important work. It also makes them feel more motivated and enjoy work more.



How to become an AI power user?


If the research findings are anything to go by, then becoming an AI power user is the way to go to further career progression. So, what are the habits that mark out a power user? According to the 2024 Work Trend Index, it’s some of the following:


Experiment with different ways of using AI: power users are more than two-thirds more likely than other survey respondents to do so.
Always ask yourself, “How can AI help?”: power users are nearly 50% more likely to pause to explore what AI could contribute before tackling a new task, to keep trying if they don’t get the perfect response the first time (+30%), for example, by researching new prompts (+56%).
‘Bookend’ your working day with AI: 9 in 10 power users use AI tools to start their day and get set up for the next day.
Redesign your ways of working with AI and save time: power users are much more likely than other respondents to use AI for a wide range of tasks, including catching up on meetings, analyzing information, designing visual content, brainstorming ideas and even interacting with customers.
Redesign business processes with AI: power users don’t just stop at reorganizing their own ways of working; they are also 66% more likely to redesign entire business processes and workflows in the organization using AI tools.


Getting business and education ready for the AI future


With PwC finding that skillsets for what it terms ‘AI-exposed occupations’ are changing 25% faster than in roles where AI is less relevant, adopting some, if not all, of these habits could dramatically improve people’s future career development.

However, the findings also mean that organizations and educational systems must do major work to prepare the current workforce and future generations for an AI-driven world of work.

As part of its mission to build more resilient, productive, equitable and human-centric workplaces, the World Economic Forum’s Good Work Alliance focuses on deploying AI effectively and responsibly. The Education 4.0 framework aims to ensure education and training systems teach AI skills and leverage AI for better learning.


This article is republished from World Economic Forum under a Creative Commons license.

headline: Top 10 AI Jobs for Non-Coders
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'givenName': 'Sumedha Sen ', 'name': 'Sumedha Sen ', 'url': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net/author/sumedha'}]
name: Top 10 AI Jobs for Non-Coders
articleBody: Today, multiple job roles are emerging in the ever-expanding field of artificial intelligence(AI). Many companies hire individuals with no programming skills, providing excellent opportunities to join this tech revolution. Here, we will explore top 10 AI jobs for non-coders, showcasing the job roles and responsibilities:.1. AI ethicist.Artificial intelligence has ignited unparalleled ethical worries, particularly about the loss of employment. Experts in AI ethics advocate for responsibility and accountability when employing artificial intelligence, reducing dangers and boosting the advantages of AI. An AI ethicist is expected to oversee moral and ethical implications that are likely to arise with the advancement of AI technologies and its various uses. Even if they may have prior technical knowledge about the subject, they have to have the complete picture of the ethical side of  artificial intelligence.Their responsibilities may include recommending how best to design AI products and products based on AI innovation, and making sure all the protocols are complied within the application stage.This position does not require anyone to be a technician based on programming, and yet it uses programming extensively.On average, AI ethics experts earn $120,000 annually, and the need for their services is expected to grow as more businesses adopt AI technologies in their operations..2. Artificial Intelligence Writers.Even though people are scared that ChatGPT can replace jobs in the content writing  industry, experienced writers have been leveraging natural language processing to succeed in the expanding field of artificial intelligence.AI content writers share their resources to help others utilize them efficiently. For instance, Writing about AI job positions to provide information to the audience. This field is ideal for individuals with basic tech skills, as all you have to do is convey creative concepts well.Numerous positions offer a minimum of $20 an hour, with some offering significantly higher rates..3. Chatbot Designer.With the rise of AI chatbots, it's anticipated that they will generate content that rivals that of human-created content. As a result, AI companies require human involvement to ensure their chatbots interact in a manner that mimics human conversation.This is done by chatbot designers in creating scripts to set the appearance of virtual customer support and map out the variety of questions customers may pose to the chatbot.These AI specialists apply attributes that go beyond pure knowledge of programming, so this position may be beneficial even if you have no direct experience in Artificial Intelligence.The typical AI UX designer earns approximately US$107,000 annually . While top-paid professionals Chatbot designers do this by coming up with scripts to create the illusion of virtual customer support and indicating various types of questions that the customer may pose to the chatbot. Hiring these AI experts should require more than just technical know-how since they will need to learn and implement knowledge that is not technical in the artificial intelligence realm, thus proving the position is perfect for anyone who does not have any coding experience in the Artificial Intelligence field.The average salary for an AI UX designer is around US$107K per year; however, the best ones can get US$120,000..3. Chatbot Designer.With the rise of AI chatbots, it's anticipated that they will generate content that rivals that of human-created content. As a result, AI companies require human involvement to ensure their chatbots interact in a manner that mimics human conversation. This is done by chatbot designers in creating scripts to set the appearance of virtual customer support and map out the variety of questions customers may pose to the chatbot.These AI specialists apply attributes that go beyond pure knowledge of programming, so this position may be beneficial even if you have no direct experience in Artificial Intelligence.The typical AI UX designer earns approximately US$107,000 annually . While top-paid professionals Chatbot designers do this by coming up with scripts to create the illusion of virtual customer support and indicating various types of questions that the customer may pose to the chatbot. Hiring these AI experts should require more than just technical know-how since they will need to learn and implement knowledge that is not technical in the artificial intelligence realm, thus proving the position is perfect for anyone who does not have any coding experience in the Artificial Intelligence field.The average salary for an AI UX designer is around US$107K per year; however, the best ones can get US$120,000..4. Prompt Engineer.Artificial intelligence chatbots have the ability to create different types of content from brief instructions, yet achieving precise outcomes can be difficult.For example, if you ask DALL-E to create a rainbow waterfall, it can come up with numerous variations of the picture, but you may not find the desired one. It is here that the role of a prompt engineer is particularly highlighted as their input is drastic on the mathematics used in this process. It is still very important to know how to create these questions in such a way that will elicit the desired responses, making this position one of the most sought by non-programmers in the AI line of work. The typical earnings for a prompt engineer are around US$335,000..5. Digital Artist.Artificial Intelligence-generated visuals boost the need for human-made art .Since machine learning can replicate visual appeal, it lacks the essence of human imagination. To be a digital artist, you don't have to be well-versed in deep learning or data modeling, but you need to possess artistic abilities and be familiar with digital software such as Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator. The typical earnings for a digital artist hover around US$53,013..6. AI policy and regulation specialist.Scholars and practitioners in Artificial Intelligence policy and regulation analyse the complex, real and legal environment of legal and regulatory aspects of AI. This is because AI is an area of technology that is dynamic and as such, legal frameworks are in a process of continuous development.  Issues such as data protection and AI of equal opportunity are sensitive to legal consideration.Policy makers and other legal experts involved in the establishment of AI policies and ensuring policy compliance are aware of the current and emerging legal requirements for the fields they work for.These options of the professional working in the field of specialist in AI policy and regulation will cause the typical earnings to differ depending on the sector or industry the professional is operating from..7. AI researcher (non-technical).AI researchers concentrate on the social, economic, and ethical dimensions of AI. Their studies enhance productivity, enable business forecasting, pinpoint potential dangers, and streamline mundane duties, thereby allowing present staff to concentrate on different responsibilities. These researchers can apply their expertise across numerous sectors, such as healthcare, advertising, geology, farming, and beyond. With the coming of advanced and broader technology, the practice of artificial intelligence research is also likely to spread across many other fields as well.  The potential income in the field of AI research is substantial, with some individuals earning between US$150,000 and US$250,000 annually..8. AI sales and marketing specialist.AI sales and marketing specialist are well-versed in the abilities of AI and apply this understanding to promote AI products and services to both companies and individuals. While basic knowledge of AI technologies is beneficial, the essential abilities to excel in this field are better focused on demonstrating the advantages of AI technologies and knowing how to guide customers through the procedure of integrating them in a manner that supports their primary business goals. The BLS reports that an average employee working in the sales and marketing context gets a pay of about US$38 per hour which translates to roughly US$79 000 per year..9. AI solutions consultant.AI solutions consultant guides businesses in developing and enhancing various AI elements, including chatbots, virtual helpers, and other functionalities driven by artificial intelligence. They shine when it comes to project delivery and involvement across the project life cycle whereby they might support in formulation of strategies, technical expertise and implementation of the solutions.They have the experience in determining which are the right skills and technologies to apply in order to develop the best AI solutions as well as who are the reliable professionals to transform a company into a digital enterprise that is capable of implementing various AI technologies.These experts may focus on specific areas such as assessment, deployment, strategy creation, training, and adherence to regulations. Some concentrate on technology or cloud consulting, while others provide comprehensive solutions to manage all processes involving AI..10. Game Writer.Artificial intelligence has been incorporated into contemporary video games, allowing them to generate realistic visuals and incorporate authentic motions in their characters. Nonetheless, the majority of game development companies still favor handcrafted scripts for dialogue that sounds more organic, rendering this position highly desirable for AI positions that do not require programming skills.The yearly earnings of a game script creator typically range from $56,417 to $70,000..Tips to secure top 10 AI jobs for non-coders.Here are a few suggestions to assist you in excelling in top 10 AI jobs for non-coders:.1. Understand the BasicsEven if you're not coding, it's helpful to grasp the basics of AI. Learn about machine learning, natural language processing, and data analysis. 2. Identify your strength Figure out what skills you already have that could be useful in AI roles for non-coders. For instance, if you're great at communicating, you might be a good fit for an AI ethics advisor or a data analytics translator. 3. Eagerness to learn new thingsThe world of AI is always changing. Stay interested and keep up with the latest advancements and their effects on your job. 4. Build ConnectionsReach out to experts in the AI sector. Go to events, join online groups, and take part in online talks to learn from others and find new chances. 5. Get CertificationYou don't need a technical degree, but getting certified in AI or a similar area can boost your reputation and lead to more job prospects.6. Highlight Your AbilitiesIn your job applications for AI roles that don't require coding, emphasize your skills and experiences in your application materials. Show how you can add value to the company's AI projects.Whether you're looking to transition into the AI field or simply curious about the opportunities available, these top 10 AI jobs for non-coders offer a promising start. The key to success in these positions lies in understanding AI's capabilities and its impact on various industries. .FAQs.Which IT field is best without coding?.The best IT field without coding is cybersecurity. Professionals focus on protecting systems and data from cyber threats, implementing security protocols, and conducting risk assessments. Other non-coding IT fields include project management, IT support, and data analysis, where technical knowledge is crucial, but direct coding skills are optional..Does the domain AI offer high-paying jobs?.Yes, the domain of artificial intelligence (AI) offers high-paying jobs. AI specialists, machine learning engineers, and data scientists are in high demand, commanding lucrative salaries due to their expertise in developing intelligent systems, algorithms, and data analysis. The growing reliance on AI across industries further boosts the earning potential in this field..How can I start a career in AI?.To start a career in AI, learn programming languages like Python and gain a strong foundation in mathematics, particularly statistics and linear algebra. Then, take online courses or obtain a degree in AI or related fields, work on projects to build practical experience, and network with professionals in the industry..Will AI jobs be in demand?.AI jobs will be in high demand as industries increasingly adopt AI technologies to improve efficiency, decision-making, and innovation. The growth of AI applications in various sectors like healthcare, finance, and automation ensures a steady need for skilled AI professionals, making it a promising career path for the future..What is the best coding AI course for non-coders?.The best coding AI course for non-coders is "AI for Everyone" by Andrew Ng on Coursera. It provides a comprehensive introduction to AI concepts without requiring programming skills, making it accessible for beginners and professionals from non-technical backgrounds.

og:description:
The UiPath survey found that 60% of workers in Singapore actively use generative AI (Gen AI) at work to solve work problems.
#uipath #ai #generativeai
article text:
We’re #1! Survey reveals that Singaporean workers use generative AI the most at work
Jess O’Reilly, Area Vice President, Asia at UiPath. Image source: UiPath.
Singaporean Millennial and Gen Z workers are more likely to use Gen AI tools at work and have seen greater time-saving benefits from implementing these tools compared to older generations. At least that is according to the findings of a global survey of 9,047 full-time employees from nine countries from business automation company UiPath.
According to the survey, 60% of local workers have used generative AI during work hours to solve work problems. These have included, drafting communications (44%), summarising long-form content (34%), and brainstorming (34%).

Uncertainty gives rise to burning out
Against the backdrop of increasingly challenging economic conditions, Singaporean workers are facing increasing workloads and almost a third (30%) of employees in Singapore indicated feeling extremely or very burnt out.
To reduce this, Singaporean workers want their workload reduced (62%), more time and bandwidth to get tasks done (46%), and access to AI and automation, including Gen AI tools (43%).
This is because Gen AI is seen as a potential solution to combat burnout by giving employees time back in their day. 62% of Singaporean workers who use Gen AI at work believe it has saved them time on work-related tasks, with more than 42% saving 10 or more hours.
Jess O’Reilly, Area Vice President, Asia at UiPath said: 
The findings from our survey indicate that Singaporean workers who do utilise both technologies (Gen AI and automation) have seen greater productivity and an improved work life balance. To inculcate a more fulfilled workforce, initiatives to plug skill gaps, foster greater trust in AI, as well as strategic private-public partnerships will be key to help workers embrace digital transformation in the age of AI.
The results of this survey serve to reinforce why the Singapore Government, working with partners DataRobot, IBM, Singtel, and Temasek, launched Project Moonshot. This is a testing toolkit designed to address security and safety challenges often associated with the use of large language models (LLMs), the cornerstone of many AI-driven solutions.
headline: We’re #1! Survey reveals that Singaporean workers use generative AI the most at work

article text:
Artificial intelligenceHybrid workingLatest NewsJob creation and lossesTech sector 

No sign that generative AI is replacing jobs

by Rob Moss
18 Jun 2024 

by Rob Moss
18 Jun 2024
Stokkete/Shutterstock 

Stokkete/Shutterstock 



Increased use of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) is not replacing jobs, according to a pulse survey of technology leaders.
Research by Nash Squared, a global provider of technology and talent solutions, found that although 74% of UK tech leaders have deployed GenAI to at least some extent to employees, almost all (99%) say it is not replacing jobs.
Half (51%) said they are using GenAI as a personal productivity tool to support existing jobs, to make them more effective.
Bev White, CEO of Nash Squared, said: “Although the ’replace-jobs’ impact of GenAI is headline-grabbing news, in our discussions with tech leaders there is a sense that its impact will be evolutionary rather than revolutionary.
“As organisations change and grow, AI will be stitched into the operations and structure; its impact happening bit by bit. In fact, the pulse survey indicates that organisations with company-wide implementations of GenAI are in fact more likely to be increasing tech headcount in the next year than the average.”
The research also found that, as GenAI is being rapidly rolled out more widely, appointments of a chief AI officer (CAIO) is increasing with one in 20 UK organisations already having a person in the role and a similar proportion planning to appoint one.

GenAI and job creation
HR ‘unprepared’ for AI workforce revolution
How HR can make the most of AI 2.0
UK below Honduras in tech and business skill ranking

But for the majority of organisations, AI strategy still sits with the tech leader, the chief information or technology officers.
The survey also found that to support employees and ensure the safe use of GenAI in their organisations, UK tech leaders have rapidly rolled out GenAI policies, with the number with a policy in place doubling in just six months.
For many, this has been a “retrofit” policy after GenAI has been adopted, but almost four in 10 tech leaders remain concerned about the misuse of GenAI tools.
Tech leaders in the UK see the potential of AI, but 55% have yet to find a clear business case beyond a personal productivity tool, and 27% are struggling with budgetary constraints.
White added: “There’s no doubt there have been some incredible advances. One tech leader mentioned how the last year has seen a giant leap in cancer screening through AI – good news for us all. Another talks about how machine learning has supported the fundraising revenue for their higher education institution, opening access to a wider student population.”
The research found that 43% expect to increase their tech budget, and 36% plan to increase their tech headcount.
Nineteen per cent of respondents say they have increased the number of days employees are expected in the office. For those organisations where employees are mandated to be in the office, the typical time expected has moved from 2-3 days to 3 days. Most leaders are happy with the results: 42% say it is working ‘extremely well’ (up 20% in six months), while 45% say ‘quite well’, although some say more days in the office does have consequences, especially on diverse hiring.
The survey was carried out in May 2024 among 322 tech leaders globally including 182 in the UK.

Rob Moss
Rob Moss is a business journalist with more than 25 years' experience. He has been editor of Personnel Today since 2010. He joined the publication in 2006 as online editor of the award-winning website. Rob specialises in labour market economics, gender diversity and family-friendly working. He has hosted hundreds of webinar and podcasts. Before writing about HR and employment he ran news and feature desks on publications serving the global optical and eyewear market, the UK electrical industry, and energy markets in Asia and the Middle East.

headline: Top 10 Generative AI Recruiters in India
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'givenName': 'Swathi Kashettar', 'name': 'Swathi Kashettar', 'url': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net/author/swathi-kashettar'}]

itemListElement: [{'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 1, 'name': 'Home', 'item': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net'}, {'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 2, 'name': 'Generative AI', 'item': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net/generative-ai'}, {'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 3, 'name': 'Top 10 Generative AI Recruiters in India', 'item': 'https://www.analyticsinsight.net/generative-ai/top-10-generative-ai-recruiters-in-india'}]
articleBody: The tech landscape in India is paced with changes, one after the other. Generative AI is on the top gear of this change. There are some organizations that are not only investing in the development of new AI-driven solutions but are also among the largest recruiters in any given field, drawing talent from within the country and abroad..They are the ones shaping the future of AI in the country, driving innovation, and setting the ball rolling for the country to emerge as leaders in the space of generative AI. Following is the list of top 10 Generative AI recruiters gaining ground in this exciting domain:.1. Tata Consultancy Services Limited: As a behemoth in the Indian IT industry, TCS launched a dedicated Generative AI solution. It collaborated with Amazon Web Services to help businesses deliver the most current AI innovations. TCS has been heavily upskilling its workforce—over 100,000 employees are trained in generative AI, while more than 25,000 are certified in AWS's specific generative AI services.This extensive training program puts them in a position to become a one-stop destination in business. There will, hence, be a need for Generative AI recruiters to source the right kind of talent that is required in the various new roles created within TCS.2. Larsen & Toubro Limited (L&T): Recognizing the ability of Generative AI to be the game changer, the multinational conglomerate L&T has taken steps to begin upskilling its talent pool. They plan to do this by training 1,000 engineers on NVIDIA technologies—maniacal leader of hardware and software AI solutions—meant to arm their engineers with expertise in harnessing generative AI in different applications.3. Infosys Technologies Private Limited: Infosys, an IT Services leader, doesn't get tired of touting innovation, for Infosys Topaz, its AI-first platform, has already been put together on the backbone of Generative AI. Solutions for specific industries vary based on different business needs.Further, a partnership with NVIDIA for the acceleration of Generative AI across industries only opens up more opportunities for Generative AI recruiters connecting candidates experienced in both NVIDIA technologies and Generative AI models..4. Tech Mahindra Limited: Against the backdrop of digital change in today's world, Generative AI finds usage through Tech Mahindra's "Ops amplifAIer" initiative. This is an AI-powered solutions in the automation of regular tasks and advanced arming of tools to IT support engineers against complex queries. Generative AI recruiters can play a key role in identifying candidates who truly understand IT Support Operations and, at the same time, have experience in applying Generative AI solutions.5. Dubverse.ai: This young startup is using generative AI, machine learning, and natural language processing to offer video dubbing. Dubverse.ai empowers creators to translate and dub videos in over 30 languages at a speed much faster than usual. Generative AI recruiters would target media and entertainment domain expertise for candidates who can work on the development and application of solutions with Generative AI at Dubverse.ai.6. Amazon Web Services: Though it is not an Indian company, this certainly is contributing a lot towards developing generative AI around the world. It provides the full set of cloud computing services necessary for building the necessary infrastructure that helps underpin several AI applications, including generative AI.It is important to understand what role AWS can and does play in the development of generative AI. This information shall also be very instrumental for recruiters who seek candidates with expertise in the development and deployment of models of generative AI on the AWS cloud platform..7. Outplay Technologies LLP- Founded in 2017, Outplay Technologies develops AI-powered solutions designed to improve productivity and effectiveness for any sales professional. Their area of focus creates a niche demand for generative AI recruiters who truly understand a host of unique challenges and opportunities within the domain of sales.8. Rephrase.ai- Rephrase.ai is the most recent of companies using generative AI to synthesize videos. Formed in 2019, it rose very fast to an industry leader by helping businesses all across the globe with professional-grade, hyper-personalized videos. The company envisions a humanized world personified by one personal video after another. On its way to this ideal vision, generated over 250,000 videos for 50 clients in the enterprise. Three dynamic leaders move Rephrase.ai, are recognized in Forbes 30 under 30 Asia 2021. It comprises a strength of more than 50 members in the team. Rephrase.ai says that ideas take precedence over hierarchy, and work culture is all about hiring the best talent toward giving life to our vision.9. Glean Search Technologies India Private Limited – It is a forward-looking company that has embraced the power of generative AI to change enterprise search and knowledge discovery. They provide a platform that unlocks all the power of generative AI and makes it possible for business people, thereafter, to make better decisions faster by putting their company's knowledge into action.Glean's AI platform includes a knowledge graph, advanced personalization, and retrieval augmented generation, all working in tandem to achieve greater accessibility and utility of enterprise data. They are looking to recruit some brilliant minds that will help them take this vision of bringing knowledge to people—making a difference in the world—one step further.10. Persistent GenAI Hub- Persistent GenAI Hub—a platform designed to generate quick, efficient, and responsible creation of AI experiences in generative AI is developed. This will allow enterprises to adopt generative AI within varying large language models and across multiple clouds without getting locked into the provider. It easily integrates with any existing assets and is powered by pre-built accelerators. Apart from that, Persistent Systems has further collaborated with Google Cloud to announce a set of Google Cloud-powered generative AI solutions.Backed by more than 16,000 technical and sales professionals trained in AI, they mean business with regard to the technology, their readiness to meet the fast-growing demand for AI solution is evident..From health to entertainment, generative AI is making a foray across sectors in India. The uses are as exciting as they are pervasive. Discussed here is how generative AI is being applied across industries in India..· Healthcare: Gen AI finds applications in healthcare, where it is used in the personalization of health plans. Different treatment plans can be generated for a patient by this generative AI, simulating different medical scenarios useful in training. It's also aiding in drug discovery, predicting molecular structures and their interactions.· Finance: Generative AI in the financial sector aids in fraud detection. It helps generate models of fraud behaviors. It is also applied to algorithmic trading as the AI systems are capable of generating predictive models about market trends.· Customer Service: Next, generative AI has made AI chatbots and virtual assistants more human-like in dealing efficiently with customer queries and giving personal recommendations..· Content Creation: In its various created-media forms, generative AI is really pushing the envelope on creating new forms of content: articles, videos, music, and even realistic visual effects in movie animations.· Education: Generative AI is being applied to the creation of personalized learning experiences for students through the generation of custom educational content and adaptive learning paths.· Automotive: It creates thousands of design variations; generative AI designs new models in the car industry. After that, they can be rapidly evaluated and reﬁned.· Retailers will leverage generative AI to bring customer style trends into reality ahead of the market view and design new products accordingly. Another in inventory management is prediction with maintaining optimum chain stock..· Manufacturing: Long before, predictive maintenance changed manufacturing—now, AI can guess when machines will need servicing; generative design changed how AI designs new product designs.· Agriculture: The major applications of generative AI at work in agriculture go to crop yield prediction and generation of optimal sowing patterns for efficiency and sustainability.

Title: Will Generative AI Deliver Unprecedented Business Productivity Gains? - Forbes
description: Brynjolfsson is a powerful advocate of the productivity potential that can be achieved through AI, envisioning double-digit gains in economic productivity.
og:description: Brynjolfsson is a powerful advocate of the productivity potential that can be achieved through AI, envisioning double-digit gains in economic productivity.
twitter:description: Brynjolfsson is a powerful advocate of the productivity potential that can be achieved through AI, envisioning double-digit gains in economic productivity.
article text:
More From ForbesJul 21, 2024,05:53pm EDTMontgomery Officials Plan Civil Rights March In MetaverseJul 20, 2024,12:13pm EDTCrowdStrike Incident Spurs CIOs To Reassess CybersecurityJul 16, 2024,10:47am EDTChristopher Conrad Joins Ralph Lauren As Digital And Technology ChiefJul 15, 2024,03:23pm EDTFrom Pilot To Production in Generative AI: 3 Lessons LearnedJul 14, 2024,09:06pm EDTCrossing The AI Chasm With Technology Thinker And Visionary Geoffrey MooreJul 13, 2024,07:00am EDTAT&T Board Gifted 100 Million Customers’ Privacy To HackersJul 8, 2024,08:00am EDTHow To Tackle Technical Debt...And Survive, Volume 2Edit StoryForbesLeadershipCIO NetworkWill Generative AI Deliver Unprecedented Business Productivity Gains?Randy BeanContributorOpinions expressed by Forbes Contributors are their own.Randy Bean is a noted Senior Advisor, Author, Speaker, Founder, & CEO.FollowingFollowClick to save this article.You'll be asked to sign into your Forbes account.Got itJun 16, 2024,09:09pm EDTShare to FacebookShare to TwitterShare to LinkedinErik BrynjolfssonStanford HAI
In a 2018 Financial Times article, The Long Wait for a Productivity Resurgence, it was noted that “No economist has done more to promote the revolutionary implications of information technology than MIT’s Erik Brynjolfsson”. Brynjolfsson was then professor at MIT’s Sloan School of Management, a role he held for 20 years, while also serving as director of the MIT Initiative on the Digital Economy (IDE). During his two decades at MIT, Brynjolfsson distinguished himself as one of the world’s leading researchers on productivity and work, and on the economics of information, AI, and the digital economy. An economist by training, Brynjolfsson has focused on how AI drives productivity. When it comes to the business productivity implications of AI, who better to provide a perspective on the current state of AI and its potential to transform work.


I first met Erik Brynjolfsson during his tenure at MIT. At the time, I attended a number of IDE events, and Brynjolfsson joined me for one of a series of Fortune 1000 CIO roundtable tables that I organized and hosted during these years. When I published my book, Fail Fast, Learn Faster: Lessons in Data Driven Leadership in an Age of Disruption, Big Data, and AI, in 2021, I referenced Brynjolfsson’s pioneering work at the intersection of digital, data, and AI, which was years ahead of its time. In works such as 2016’s The Second Machine Age, co-authored with Andrew McAfee, and in a 2017 MIT Sloan Management Review article, “How to Thrive – and Survive – in a World of AI Disruption”, Brynjolfsson anticipated the impact that AI would have on work and business productivity.

In June 2020, during the COVID outbreak, Brynjolfsson was presented with the opportunity to relocate across the country to become the Jerry Yang and Akiko Yamazaki Professor and Senior Fellow with Stanford University in Palo Alto, and to launch the Digital Economy Lab at the Stanford Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI). The mission of the Digital Economy Lab is to improve our understanding of the economic implications of the rapid improvements in AI and other digital technologies. Led by Brynjolfsson, it includes faculty from multiple departments across Stanford. Research focuses on developing new economic models and empirical research, including measuring, forecasting and guiding the human and societal impact of AI, and particularly in ways that create widely shared prosperity.

PROMOTED
I had the opportunity to catch up with Brynjolfsson in recent weeks. Brynjolfsson’s research examines the effects of not only AI but also other information technologies on business strategy, productivity and performance, and digital commerce. He believes that the impact of a changing economy will be felt by everyone, crossing boundaries of wealth, status, geography, and culture. Central to the mission of the Lab is a belief in the power of human work, and a belief that augmenting human capabilities with machine capabilities through AI will lead to beneficial gains for everyone. As Brynjolfsson noted as far back in 2017 “AI won’t replace managers, but managers who use AI will replace those who don’t.”

I asked Brynjolfsson how it felt to relocate to the West Coast and in close proximity to Silicon Valley. Brynjolfsson expressed deep love for MIT but added that it was invigorating to be near and a part of such a strong innovation community, both at Stanford and in Silicon Valley. I noted that I had recently had the opportunity to hear HAI director Fei-Fei Li speak at the Wall Street Journal Tech Live event in Laguna Beach and had written about that experience, and been inspired to read her memoir about her life in AI. HAI has assembled a strong leadership team and distinguished fellows, including the recent announcement that noted MIT researcher Sandy Pentland would be joining the HAI team as part of Brynjolfsson’s Digital Economy Lab.
MORE FROMFORBES ADVISORBest High-Yield Savings Accounts Of 2024ByKevin PayneContributorBest 5% Interest Savings Accounts of 2024ByCassidy HortonContributor
Brynjolfsson recently participated in an extensive interview with the Financial Times, which appeared under the headline, “Erik Brynjolfsson: ‘This Could be The Best Decade in History – or the Worst”. I asked Brynjolfsson about his perspective on AI in the context of history, and where he would place AI among the pantheon of transformative technologies. “I think it’s most comparable to the Industrial Revolution” commented Brynjolfsson, noting however that, “while the Industrial Revolution played out over more than a century, AI will play out much faster, in a matter of a few decades”. AI is coming along “faster than anyone really expected” added Brynjolfsson, citing AI in healthcare as an area of great potential for human good.









CxO
US

                Sign Up

Forbes is protected by reCAPTCHA, and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.




You’re all set! Enjoy the CEO newsletter!

You’re all set! Enjoy the CEO newsletter!

                More Newsletters
            



I noted that in his Financial Times interview, Brynjolfsson had commented that people often use AGI – artificial general intelligence — as a synonym for human-level intelligence. However, “I think it will become apparent that humans have a narrow kind of intelligence and that truly general intelligence will have a much broader set of capabilities”. This was not something I commonly hear, so I asked Brynjolfsson to elaborate. This led to a discussion of augmentation, and how AI can and should be used to augment human skills and intelligence, which is at the heart of driving improved productivity. Brynjolfsson explained that technologists need to look at how AI can be used not just to “imitate or repeat human tasks”, but how AI can be used to “augment and complement” employees.


1/1





Skip Ad
 
Continue watchingafter the adVisit Advertiser websiteGO TO PAGE
As an extension of his commitment to improving productivity, Brynjolfsson is embarking on a new business venture focused on “task-based analysis”, which refers to the concept of looking at tens of thousands of tasks and ranking them based on which tasks AI can help the most with. Brynjolfsson has launched a venture, Workhelix, which combines research and data to quantitatively assess a company’s GenAI opportunity. Workhelix co-founder and CEO James Milin explains, “The approach that we’ve pioneered starts with a granular question: can GenAI double the productivity of a task without reducing quality?” He continues, “Using our algorithms and data, we answer this question for every task in an organization, then work upward to understand how jobs, and ultimately each company, can benefit from GenAI”.
Brynjolfsson is a powerful advocate of the productivity potential that can be achieved through AI, envisioning double-digit gains in economic productivity, and commenting that he foresees the potential for “massive economic disruption” leading to the creation of new occupations and new companies in the coming years. Brynjolfsson believes this can lead to greater social benefits, manifested in the form of higher wages and greater prosperity. He expands upon this thesis in an article, The Turing Trap: The Promise and Peril of Human-Like Artificial Intelligence, noting that, “When AI is focused on augmenting humans rather than mimicking them, than humans retain the power to insist on a share of the value you created”. He adds, “Augmentation creates new capabilities and new products and services”.
As with any technology and period of historic transformation, responsibility ultimately resides with us as human beings. Brynjolfsson has argued that because we have more powerful tools than ever before “this could be the best decade in history – or the worst”, noting that “misinformation, viruses or weapons, cyber-attacks, and phishing attacks” remain threats. He points to risks posed by information overload, fake news, and other nefarious uses. Brynjolfsson concludes that the future of AI will largely depend on the steps we take today as humans to place a premium on intelligent governance, safeguards, and guardrails. Brynjolfsson warns us simply, “We should not fly blind.”

headline: How AI is reshaping fashion’s workforce
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Savannah Fortis', 'sameAs': 'https://www.voguebusiness.com/contributor/savannah-fortis'}]
articleBody:
This article on generative AI is part of our Vogue Business membership package. To enjoy unlimited access to our weekly Technology Edit, which contains Member-only reporting and analysis and our NFT Tracker, sign up for membership here.
Generative artificial intelligence is poised to change how fashion works, but whether that’s good news or bad news might depend on what job you’re doing.
If you’re in control of budgets, AI offers opportunities to cut headcounts or reallocate resources more profitably. However, if you’re starting out in a career, AI could reduce opportunity, particularly in starter roles.
As tasks become faster and easier, brands see an opportunity to shift some manual tasks from humans to machines. First up for streamlining: human-led and often time-consuming roles, such as copywriting, coding, customer service, clienteling, photo editing and 3D design and illustration.
Brands are already utilising the power of AI to cut production and operations costs. In May, LVMH awarded its 2024 Innovation Award to Chinese startup FancyTech, a platform that is collaborating with LVMH brands. FancyTech uses generative artificial intelligence to produce videos from 3D product models and creative briefs. A separate prize went to Blng, an LA-based company that uses AI to convert sketches of jewellery into visualisations. Meanwhile, AI investment from the likes of LVMH-owned Sephora is focused on improving chatbots to supercharge the customer experience online.
The Estée Lauder Companies is using generative AI to measure customer sentiment, aid in writing copy and make product recommendations; a new innovation lab, with Microsoft, is developing tools that help internal teams identify and respond to trends, such as an internal chatbot that helps brands source products that identify specific problems. Revolve has tested it for generating new product designs, while Adore Me is enabling customers to customise their own bra and panty sets. Adore Me also uses generative AI to inform SEO-optimised product descriptions, but VP of strategy Ranjan Roy says that, ultimately, any copy customers end up seeing is approved and finalised by human employees.
AI provides opportunities in the fashion and retail sectors across multiple categories, according to Lamees Butt, CEO and founder of Riser, an AI-powered career matchmaking app for brands — “from the way trends are consumed and created to the retail customer journey”. It will “profoundly impact” the workforce, particularly in roles related to design, marketing and customer service, Butt says.
Some businesses have moved fast to maximise the opportunity. Swedish e-commerce payment company Klarna says AI has contributed to 37 per cent of its cost savings, equating to $10 million annually, for tasks related to external marketing, image production and general company efficiency.
A study from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), released in January, suggests that almost 40 per cent of employment worldwide is exposed to AI. Advanced economies are most exposed, while also being better positioned to leverage its benefits.
Roles such as retail specialists and store managers will “take the heat more than others”, says Adam Jackson, founder and CEO of AI recruiting app Braintrust, but he sees change everywhere. “AI is automating tasks like trend prediction, inventory management, and even churning out creative clothing patterns.”
Talented employees or applicants need not worry, he assures. “Many retailers are deploying AI to their advantage, focusing on hiring the right talent, as opposed to collecting the most résumés,” he says.
The ability to work with AI is becoming an essential skill to add to the average CV. Fashion job boards are introducing roles that require AI competency, such as data governance managers at LVMH or data scientists at Estée Lauder Companies — roles that require candidates to be comfortable with the “implementation of AI capabilities”.
Mindful implementation
As fashion and retail hurries to implement generative AI solutions, experts warn of the risks of moving too fast.
For all its potential, AI could prompt a knee-jerk response from overexcited business leaders. Partha Gopalakrishnan, president of Brane Group, a consultancy specialising in AI solutions, and a former senior executive at Infosys, has noted “a spate of layoffs, teething errors in retailers’ systems and even big firms ceasing working with creative agencies and freelancers”.
Gopalakrishnan is concerned that the human factor may be neglected by fashion executives prioritising quick-win opportunities. “Fashion and retail executives need to take a step back and rethink their approach. [The industry] needs to invest in talent, culture and training first, and then it can start to fold AI into its operations,” he says.
He suggests that retailers should be looking to employ “highly adaptable candidates” with the ability to unlearn and relearn, complemented by the introduction of comprehensive internal training and upskilling.
In the interim, some governments are stepping in to alleviate concerns around the impact. Last autumn, for example, the US Biden administration issued an executive order calling for support when it comes to job training, with hopes to mitigate job displacement.
Some companies, already in this mindset, have invested in training programmes to help employees gain AI and data analysis skills. Nike, for example, deploys AI-powered tools that provide its senior leadership team with access to custom analytics tailored to support decision-making. Tapestry-owned Coach has an internal dashboard that provides relevant data to all employees, enabling staff to understand trends and make more informed recommendations. German-based Hugo Boss has worked with external consultancy Metyis to build out what it describes as a “dedicated data science campus”.
Upskilling
Momentum is building in upskilling teams. Estée Lauder and Microsoft have collaborated on creating an AI innovation lab to upskill Estée Lauder employees. The company is able to use Microsoft’s tech expertise to develop in-house solutions that are specific to its business, and therefore didn’t require additional employees to build out these efforts.
Altava Group, a fashion-tech company that emerged from LVMH’s La Maison des Startups business accelerator, has launched a proprietary generative AI tool for accessible 3D fashion design. The business is upskilling its team and hiring employees with specific skill sets relating to machine learning and AI, says founder and CEO Andy Ku. “We are upskilling our team in distributed computing, blockchain and data learning — considering [the development of] our AI engine and our [new] target vertical, which includes 3D asset and item creation using data from our experience in luxury fashion use cases.”
Riser’s Butt advises brands to use AI tools that keep human connection and creativity — known to be key drivers of success — front of mind. “People and purpose are the most powerful parts of any brand,” says Butt. “The companies that will win are those open to embracing new solutions that blend technology with a human-centric approach, ensuring that AI enhances — rather than replaces — the unique value that only people can bring.”
Sign up to receive the Vogue Business newsletter for the latest luxury news and insights, plus exclusive membership discounts.
Comments, questions or feedback? Email us at feedback@voguebusiness.com.
alternativeHeadline: Generative AI will transform industries, including fashion, but there are downsides as well as upsides to the fast-developing technology.

Title: Adobe Says It Won't Train AI Using Artists' Work. Creatives Aren't Convinced - WIRED
description: After a user backlash, Adobe has been forced to clarify how it will use creators’ work. But can it be trusted?
keywords: ['business', 'artificial intelligence', 'machine learning', 'design', 'algorithms', 'art', 'textaboveleftsmall', 'web']
og:description: Adobe has issued new wording to explain how users’ content will be treated, after a backlash earlier this month from artists who believed their work will be used to train AI.
twitter:description: Adobe has issued new wording to explain how users’ content will be treated, after a backlash earlier this month from artists who believed their work will be used to train AI.
article text: Tiffany NgBusinessJun 19, 2024 1:59 PMAdobe Says It Won’t Train AI Using Artists’ Work. Creatives Aren’t ConvincedAfter a user backlash, Adobe has been forced to clarify how it will use creators’ work. But can it be trusted?Photograph: Justin Sullivan/Getty ImagesSave this storySaveSave this storySaveWhen users first found out about Adobe’s new terms of service (which were quietly updated in February), there was an uproar. Adobe told users it could access their content “through both automated and manual methods” and use “techniques such as machine learning in order to improve [Adobe’s] Services and Software.” Many understood the update as the company forcing users to grant unlimited access to their work, for purposes of training Adobe’s generative AI, known as Firefly.Late on Tuesday, Adobe issued a clarification: In an updated version of its terms of service agreement, it pledged not to train AI on its users' content stored locally or in the cloud and gave users the option to opt out of content analytics.Caught in the crossfire of intellectual property lawsuits, the ambiguous language used to previously update the terms shed light on a climate of acute skepticism among artists, many of whom overrely on Adobe for their work. “They already broke our trust,” says Jon Lam, a senior storyboard artist at Riot Games, referring to how award-winning artist Brian Kesinger discovered generated images in the style of his art being sold under his name on Adobe's stock image site, without his consent. Earlier this month, the estate of late photographer Ansel Adams publicly scolded Adobe for allegedly selling generative AI imitations of his work.Trending NowMoistCr1TiKaL Answers The Web's Most Searched QuestionsScott Belsky, Adobe’s chief strategy officer, had tried to assuage concerns when artists started protesting, clarifying that machine learning refers to the company’s non-generative AI tools—Photoshop’s “Content Aware Fill” tool, which allows users to seamlessly remove objects in an image, is one of the many tools done through machine learning. But while Adobe insists that the updated terms do not give the company content ownership and that it will never use user content to train Firefly, the misunderstanding triggered a bigger discussion about the company’s market monopoly and how a change like this could threaten the livelihoods of artists at any point. Lam is among the artists who still believe that, despite Adobe’s clarification, the company will use work created on its platform to train Firefly without the creators’ consent.The nervousness over nonconsensual use and monetization of copyrighted work by generative AI models is not new. Early last year, artist Karla Ortiz was able to prompt images of her work using her name on various generative AI models, an offense that gave rise to a class action lawsuit against Midjourney, DeviantArt, and Stability AI. Ortiz was not alone—Polish fantasy artist Greg Rutkowski found that his name was one of the most commonly used prompts in Stable Diffusion when the tool first launched in 2022.As the owner of Photoshop and creator of PDFs, Adobe has reigned as the industry standard for over 30 years, powering the majority of the creative class. An attempt to acquire product design company Figma was blocked and abandoned in 2023 for antitrust concerns attesting to its size.Most PopularSecurityHow One Bad CrowdStrike Update Crashed the World’s ComputersBy Lily Hay NewmanThe Big StoryPriscila, Queen of the Rideshare MafiaBy Lauren SmileyCultureThe 29 Best Shows on Apple TV+ Right NowBy Angela WatercutterCultureThe 19 Best Movies on Amazon Prime Right NowBy Matt KamenAdobe specifies that Firefly is “ethically trained” on Adobe Stock, but Eric Urquhart, longtime stock image contributor, insists that “there was nothing ethical about how Adobe trained the AI for Firefly,” pointing out that Adobe does not own the rights to any images from individual contributors. Urquhart originally put his images up on Fotolia, a stock image site, where he agreed to licensing terms that did not specify any uses for generative AI. Fotolia was then acquired by Adobe in 2015, which rolled out silent terms-of-service updates that later allowed the company to train Firefly using Urquhart’s photos without his explicit consent: “The language in the current change of TOS, it’s very similar to what I saw in the Adobe Stock TOS.”AdvertisementSince the introduction of Firefly, some artists have made the difficult (and arduous) decision to cancel their Adobe membership by pivoting to tools like Affinity and Clip Studio. Others feel forcefully bound to the software. “Professionally, I can’t quit Adobe,” says Urquhart.Adobe has acknowledged its responsibility to the creative community in the past. In September 2023, the company announced the Federal Anti-Impersonation Right (FAIR) act, a legislative initiative that aims to protect artists from misappropriations of their work. The proposal only addresses intentional impersonations used for commercial purposes, raising questions around efficacy (the act would not protect works ‘accidentally generated’ in the style of an artist) and privacy (proving intent would require storing and monitoring user prompts.)Outside of Adobe, organizations are finding new ways to help authenticate works and prevent intellectual property theft. A team of researchers at the University of Chicago developed Nightshade, a tool that “poisons” training data and damages iterations of image-generating AI models, and Glaze, a tool that helps artists “mask” their signature styles from AI companies. In terms of regulation, the Concept Art Association—an organization Lam is also a part of—advocates for artists rights with crowd-funded lobbying efforts.Enter your email to get the Wired newsletterclose dialogRecommended NewsletterFast ForwardA weekly dispatch from the future by Will Knight, exploring advances in AI and other technologies set to change our lives.
